results.title: The Frozen River: A GMA Book Club Pick: A Novel
results.subtitle: by        Ariel Lawhon        (Author)
results.bookDescription: NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER â€¢ GMA BOOK CLUB PICK â€¢ AN NPR BOOK OF THE YEAR â€¢ From the New York Times bestselling author of I Was Anastasia and Code Name HÃ©lÃ¨ne comes a gripping historical mystery inspired by the life and diary of Martha Ballard, a renowned 18th-century midwife who defied the legal system and wrote herself into American history.. "Fans of Outlanderâ€™s Claire Fraser will enjoy Lawhonâ€™s Martha, who is brave and outspoken when it comes to protecting the innocent. . . impressive."â€”The Washington Post. "Once again, Lawhon works storytelling magic with a real-life heroine." â€”People Magazine. Maine, 1789: When the Kennebec River freezes, entombing a man in the ice, Martha Ballard is summoned to examine the body and determine cause of death. As a midwife and healer, she is privy to much of what goes on behind closed doors in Hallowell. Her diary is a record of every birth and death, crime and debacle that unfolds in the close-knit community. Months earlier, Martha documented the details of an alleged rape committed by two of the townâ€™s most respected gentlemenâ€”one of whom has now been found dead in the ice. But when a local physician undermines her conclusion, declaring the death to be an accident, Martha is forced to investigate the shocking murder on her own.. Over the course of one winter, as the trial nears, and whispers and prejudices mount, Martha doggedly pursues the truth. Her diary soon lands at the center of the scandal, implicating those she loves, and compelling Martha to decide where her own loyalties lie.. Clever, layered, and subversive, Ariel Lawhonâ€™s newest offering introduces an unsung heroine who refused to accept anything less than justice at a time when women were considered best seen and not heard. The Frozen River is a thrilling, tense, and tender story about a remarkable woman who left an unparalleled legacy yet remains nearly forgotten to this day.

reviews.title: Ehâ€¦
reviews.body: Iâ€™m halfway through this book and considering returning it.  I canâ€™t believe this is a GMA.pick.  I simply canâ€™t get into any kind of even mild excitement for this story, which strays from what should be the central plot.  If you are a  deep New England history fanatic, you may be thrilled, but I wasnâ€™t.

reviews.title: What a fabulous book
reviews.body: Iâ€™m lucky to have read two incredibly good books back to back, Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow plus this fabulous historical mystery about a late 18th C midwife in Maine. The titular frozen river itself is so prominent as to be a character in its own right. Animals, both wild and domestic, are integral.As historical fiction, this is really top notch, set on the foundation of extensive research. As a mystery, itâ€™s equally fine. To have both in one volume is a multitude of riches. It feels like a book with the depth and intensity of 600+ pages. (It doesnâ€™t feel like a long book - itâ€™s such a page-turner that it feels relatively short.) The main characters are intricately drawn; the lesser characters are essential to crafting the plot.I had thought I wouldnâ€™t be especially interested in a midwifeâ€™s story but I was hooked from the very beginning. Be warned that thereâ€™s the gore of birth itself, plus the explicit violence of rape and murder. This is also a courtroom drama, dramatic partly because the fledgling justice system is unfamiliar to modern readers.I canâ€™t recommend this highly enough. I was riveted.

reviews.title: A great book
reviews.body: A great read.  I like to give 5 stars to books that will stick with me and that I would recommend.I read this for book club or else I probably would not have picked it up.A story that follows a midwife through generations of births.  Martha is loved by many and hated by some.  She seems to have her fingers in all kinds of things.  This book is loosely based on Martha Ballard's life.  The writing is wonderful and it is like sitting down with an old friend over tea.I learned so much about midwives.  I loved that her husband both listened to her but also trusted her and embraced her knowledge.I hated how she was treated, and all woman, by men in that time.  It frustrated me and made me angry.This is a great read, so yourself a favor and give it a go.

reviews.title: Did Not Want This Book To End!
reviews.body: What an amazing book! I am sad to put this one to rest.:-( I feel like my family is moving far away. Well written, suspenseful and heartfelt! I can't wait to read more from Ariel Lawhon! Unforgettable!

results.title: The Midnight Library: A GMA Book Club Pick: A Novel
results.subtitle: by        Matt Haig        (Author)
results.bookDescription: The #1 New York Times bestselling WORLDWIDE phenomenon Winner of the Goodreads Choice Award for Fiction | A Good Morning America Book Club Pick | Independent (London) Ten Best Books of the Year "A feel-good book guaranteed to lift your spirits."â€”The Washington Post . The dazzling reader-favorite about the choices that go into a life well lived, from the acclaimed author of How To Stop Time and The Comfort Book.. Donâ€™t miss Matt Haigâ€™s latest instant New York Times besteller, The Life Impossible, available now Somewhere out beyond the edge of the universe there is a library that contains an infinite number of books, each one the story of another reality. One tells the story of your life as it is, along with another book for the other life you could have lived if you had made a different choice at any point in your life. While we all wonder how our lives might have been, what if you had the chance to go to the library and see for yourself? Would any of these other lives truly be better?. In The Midnight Library, Matt Haig's enchanting blockbuster novel, Nora Seed finds herself faced with this decision. Faced with the possibility of changing her life for a new one, following a different career, undoing old breakups, realizing her dreams of becoming a glaciologist; she must search within herself as she travels through the Midnight Library to decide what is truly fulfilling in life, and what makes it worth living in the first place.

It carried me to the end.if you like sappy feel-good stories, this might be a perfect read.For me, it ended just as I saw after the first chapter. And I kept hoping it would surprise me, instead of repeating all of the various stories to get to the ending that I knew was coming. It feels very much written to be a movie. I wondered what english actors would be the characters.I think the author is very gifted, but would have loved to be surprised.

reviews.body: I just finished this book on January 1st. I just recently deleted my social media and read this while rocking my 3 month old baby to sleep. I have always gravitated toward slice of life, choices-matter type video games and books but this one caught my attention right away and kept it until the end. I started it as a sample and when the sample ended, I simply had to keep going. I loved the tone of voice the author had and it was easy to read and root for the main character in all of her adventures. It was a powerful read that makes you think about your own life and how to appreciate what you have. Just a really good book.

reviews.title: Such a great read

reviews.title: Enjoyed

reviews.title: Emotional Multiverse
reviews.body: There's a lot ai feel I could say about this book. This is the kind of book that a book club actually discusses instead of drinking wine and pretending that they all read it. I thoroughly enjoyed this book, but it was not an easy read.The writing was good, clear, and crisp, but the subject matter was tough. The main character wasn't very likable for the majority of the text, but neither were most of the other characters in the book at some point. Yet, I never disliked her. She just didn't seem like someone I'd want to spend a lot of time with if I knew her in the real world. By the end, I'm still not sure about that, but I'd definitely make a point to say hi to her.The multiverse/reincarnation theme throughout the story was handled in a clever and sophisticated way. There were times when I thought I'd get bored with the back and forth but I never did. The author did a good job and knowing when to pull the reader away from the theme and focus on the character and vice versa.I don't think this is something I could recommend to just anyone. I'd have to know the person well enough to give them a proper trigger warning or at least know them well enough to gauge whether this would help or harm them in their present state.With that said, I wish I could recommend this book to everyone. It's really good. And if you've ever dealt with regret, this book may be just what you need.Highly recommended to those unafraid to explore the hardest and most basic aspect of the human condition or fans of multiverse concepts.

results.title: The Women: A Novel
results.subtitle: by        Kristin Hannah        (Author)
results.bookDescription: A #1 bestseller on The New York Times, USA Today, Washington Post, and Los Angeles Times!. From the celebrated author of The Nightingale and The Four Winds comes Kristin Hannah's The Womenâ€•at once an intimate portrait of coming of age in a dangerous time and an epic tale of a nation divided.Women can be heroes. When twenty-year-old nursing student Frances â€œFrankieâ€ McGrath hears these words, it is a revelation. Raised in the sun-drenched, idyllic world of Southern California and sheltered by her conservative parents, she has always prided herself on doing the right thing. But in 1965, the world is changing, and she suddenly dares to imagine a different future for herself. When her brother ships out to serve in Vietnam, she joins the Army Nurse Corps and follows his path.. As green and inexperienced as the men sent to Vietnam to fight, Frankie is over-whelmed by the chaos and destruction of war. Each day is a gamble of life and death, hope and betrayal; friendships run deep and can be shattered in an instant. In war, she meetsâ€•and becomes one ofâ€•the lucky, the brave, the broken, and the lost.. But war is just the beginning for Frankie and her veteran friends. The real battle lies in coming home to a changed and divided America, to angry protesters, and to a country that wants to forget Vietnam. . The Women is the story of one woman gone to war, but it shines a light on all women who put themselves in harmâ€™s way and whose sacrifice and commitment to their country has too often been forgotten. A novel about deep friendships and bold patriotism, The Women is a richly drawn story with a memorable heroine whose idealism and courage under fire will come to define an era.

reviews.title: first five star of 2025
reviews.body: *SPOILER ALERT, (very small)* I donâ€™t give 5 stars easily, but as always, Kristin Hannah does it. This book keeps you heavily engaged from page two! Thennnnn you feel the feeeeeels. I can say, I predicted 90% of the book as I read on, but still some surprises. I do wish that we got a look into Ethel & Barbs reunion with Jamie, and a short look into Frankieâ€™s future a couple years ahead. Loved this book nonetheless. Pulls on all the heart strings.

reviews.title: Thank you
reviews.body: I was gifted this book for Christmas this year, well 2024. Being a female veteran who spent 15 months in Baghdad I appreciate this book tremendously. I see myself in Ethel and my best friend from the Army as Frankie. We all struggle coming home from war and this book brought those feelings back and remind us to ask for help and reach out. Itâ€™s okay to talk about the stuff we went through in war, regardless of which war.

reviews.title: So. Many. Adjectives. (A spoiler-free review)
reviews.body: I wanted to love this book. I'd have settled for liking it. The subject matter is great -- paying homage to the people, especially the medical heroes, who served in Vietnam. It's also an always welcome reminder of the importance of nurses in our lives and what happens when heroines face pre-judgment on the basis of gender.It's also a poorly written book that tries to cram everything about Vietnam into a single person's experience and ends up feeling as if Hannah was working off of a checklist.And then there are those adjectives -- the book is stuffed with them. Nine in the first two sentences alone. Descriptions of everything, including things that aren't important to the plot. Vietnam isn't just lush green, it's verdant green (which is pretty redundant). We get descriptions of what people are wearing and how they are wearing their hair in every scene. Hey, gotta remind people constantly that it's the '60s.But a description of a hospital in San Diego? Why? It's not important. We all know what a stateside hospital looks like. Everything is described down to the tiniest details while plot is often revealed in expository summaries. Every twist is telegraphed. But fashionable!OKAY, MINOR SPOILER COMINGI got to the end of the section on Vietnam and then there was a bunch of boring stuff about Frankie's return stateside. She rode off into the sunset and I was happy the book had finally ended. I turned the page to read the author's bio and was greeted with "Part Two."Go into this knowing the book is long. It's not well-written. The story is okay and there are even some parts that will make you cry. Read it if you are interested in the subject matter and don't already know that much about. You will come out educated and proud of our military.If you already know about Vietnam, you can easily skip this and not miss anything. Except a lot of adjectives.

reviews.title: 5 stars
reviews.body: Possibly my favorite Kristin Hannah novel to date. But then again, each get better and better. The story of The Women is unforgettable.

reviews.title: inspiring
reviews.body: It was horrible the way Vietnam vets were treated. They didnâ€™t start this war. They were following orders through the whole mess. They lost their lives, body parts and in some cases their souls. Most American people have finally learned to love, admire and respect our vets.

reviews.title: One of the best books about the Vietnam War
reviews.body: Although this is a novel it is overall one of the best books, I have ever read about the Vietnam War. Touches on many issues from real life experiences of repairing broken bodies right off the battlefield to PTST and the lingering effects of agent Orange. You won't be able to put it down.

reviews.title: fascinating read, slightly drawn out in parts
reviews.body: First half was 5/5 for sure!!! Super gripping read and so interesting to read a book in the POV of a female nurse in Vietnam in the Vietnam war. Second half was very drawn out in times and I often found myself wanting to skip forward, 3/5. Overall was a 4/5!

reviews.title: a moving and revealing novel of hurt and hope
reviews.body: Kristin Hannah brought the Vietnam War and its stories to life with this novel. I will never forget its impact on me.

results.bookDescription: NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER â€¢ From the author of We Begin at the End comes a soaring thriller and an epic love story that â€œhits like a sledgehammer . . . an absolutely must-read novelâ€ (Gillian Flynn, author of Gone Girl).. Brava!â€â€”Kristin Hannah, author of The Women. â€œMelds tense suspense with a powerful exploration of devotion, obsession, and love.â€â€”People (Best New Books)1975 is a time of change in America. The Vietnam War is ending. Muhammad Ali is fighting Joe Frazier. And in the smalltown of Monta Clare, Missouri, girls are disappearing.. When the daughter of a wealthy family is targeted, the most unlikely hero emergesâ€”Patch, a local boy, who saves the girl, and, in doing so, leaves heartache in his wake.. results.title: Counting Miracles: A Novel
results.subtitle: by        Nicholas Sparks        (Author)
results.bookDescription: #1 NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER â€¢ From the acclaimed author of The Longest Ride and The Notebook comes an emotional, powerful novel about wondering if we can changeâ€”or even make our peace withâ€”the path weâ€™ve taken.. â€œSparks is superb at what he does. The setting is postcard perfect. The characters are immensely likable. . . . This is a tidy miracle you can count on.â€â€”The Washington Post. Tanner Hughes was raised by his grandparents, following in his grandfatherâ€™s military footsteps to become an Army Ranger. His whole life has been spent abroad, and he is the proverbial rolling stone: happiest when off on his next adventure, zero desire to settle down.Â  But when his grandmother passes away, her last words to him are find where you belong. She also drops a bombshell, telling him the name of the father he never knewâ€”and where to find him.. Tanner is due at his next posting soon, but his curiosity is piqued, and he sets out for Asheboro, North Carolina, to ask around.Â Heâ€™s been in town less than twenty-four hours when he meets Kaitlyn Cooper, a doctor and single mom. They both feel an immediate connection; Tanner knows Kaitlyn has a story to tell, and he wants to hear it. To Kaitlyn, Tanner is mysterious, excitingâ€”and possibly leaving in just a few weeks.. Meanwhile, nearby, eighty-three-year-old Jasper lives alone in a cabin bordering a national forest. With only his old dog, Arlo, for company, he lives quietly, haunted by a tragic accident that took place decades before. When he hears rumors that a white deer has been spotted in the forestâ€”a creature of legend that inspired his father and grandfatherâ€”he becomes obsessed with protecting the deer from poachers.. As these charactersâ€™ fates orbit closer together, none of them is expecting a miracle . . . but that may be exactly what is about to alter their futures forever.

reviews.title: Numerous errors, not a typical Nicholas Sparks work
reviews.body: As an author, I love great writing and almost everything Sparks has written. But I'm sad to say this book fell way short on both. I'd like to know if any editors even worked on it with him. The story was tedious and predictable, and with the distraction of numerous errors - grammar, plot, even an amateur POV slip - it was a struggle to finish. Also, I'd like to point out that I've never left a book a less-than-4-star review, mainly because I know how hard they are to receive. But I hope the author and his publisher read this and help return his work to the quality level of The Notebook and other earlier works.

reviews.title: Nicholas Spark Hit!
reviews.body: Nicolas Sparks always delivers a solid realistic fiction book and this one doesn't disappoint.  There are two stories occurring simultaneously.  One is of elderly widow Jasper, living alone in the woods, trying to confront the realities of his lost family while protecting the land, and the nature it holds, of his North Carolina community.  The other is of the blossoming friendship of Tanner, Kaitlyn, and Kaitlyn's children.  The stories intersect, but not in a forced way.  If you're already a fan of Sparks, you'll enjoy this one as well.  If Sparks is new to you and you enjoy realistic fiction with subtle romance, you'll become a fan after Counting Miracles.

"A suspenseful thriller mixed with powerful themes such as false incarceration, the death penalty and how the legal system shows prejudice.â€ â€”Associated Press In the small Florida town of Seabrook, a young lawyer named Keith Russo was shot dead at his desk as he worked late one night. The killer left no clues. There were no witnesses, no one with a motive. But the police soon came to suspect Quincy Miller, a young Black man who was once a client of Russoâ€™s. Quincy was tried, convicted, and sent to prison for life. For twenty-two years he languished in prison, maintaining his innocence. But no one was listening. He had no lawyer, no advocate on the outside. In desperation, he writes a letter to Guardian Ministries, a small nonprofit run by Cullen Post, a lawyer who is also an Episcopal minister. Guardian accepts only a few innocence cases at a time. Cullen Post travels the country fighting wrongful convictions and taking on clients forgotten by the system. With Quincy Miller, though, he gets far more than he bargained for. Powerful, ruthless people murdered Keith Russo, and they do not want Quincy Miller exonerated. They killed one lawyer twenty-two years ago, and they will kill another without a second thought. Donâ€™t miss John Grishamâ€™s new book, THE EXCHANGE: AFTER THE FIRM, coming soon!

results.title: The Things We Cannot Say: A WWII Historical Fiction Novel
results.subtitle: by        Kelly Rimmer        (Author)
results.bookDescription: The New York Times bestsellerâ€”for fans of All the Light We Cannot See and The Tattooist of Auschwitz!. From the bestselling author of Truths I Never Told You, Before I Let You Go, and the The Warsaw Orphan, Kelly Rimmerâ€™s powerful WWII novel follows a womanâ€™s urgent search for answers to a family mystery that uncovers truths about herself that she never expected.. â€œFans of The Nightingale and Lilac Girls will adore The Things We Cannot Say.â€ â€”Pam Jenoff, New York Times bestselling author. In 1942, Europe remains in the relentless grip of war. Just beyond the tents of the refugee camp she calls home, a young woman speaks her wedding vows. Itâ€™s a decision that will alter her destinyâ€¦and itâ€™s a lie that will remain buried until the next century.. Since she was nine years old, Alina Dziak knew she would marry her best friend, Tomasz. Now fifteen and engaged, Alina is unconcerned by reports of Nazi soldiers at the Polish border, believing her neighbors that they pose no real threat, and dreams instead of the day Tomasz returns from college in Warsaw so they can be married. But little by little, injustice by brutal injustice, the Nazi occupation takes hold, and Alinaâ€™s tiny rural village, its families, are divided by fear and hate.. Then, as the fabric of their lives is slowly picked apart, Tomasz disappears. Where Alina used to measure time between visits from her beloved, now she measures the spaces between hope and despair, waiting for word from Tomasz and avoiding the attentions of the soldiers who patrol her parentsâ€™ farm. But for now, even deafening silence is preferable to grief.. Slipping between Nazi-occupied Poland and the frenetic pace of modern life, Kelly Rimmer creates an emotional and finely wrought narrative. The Things We Cannot Say is an unshakable reminder of the devastation when truth is silencedâ€¦and how it can take a lifetime to find our voice before we learn to trust it.. Donâ€™t miss Kelly Rimmerâ€™s newest novel, The Paris Agent, where a familyâ€™s innocent search for answers brings a long-forgotten, twenty-five-year-old mystery featuring two female SOE operatives comes to light! results.title: Then She Was Gone: A Novel
results.subtitle: by        Lisa Jewell        (Author)
results.bookDescription: #1 NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER From the New York Times bestselling author of Invisible Girl and None of This Is True comes a â€œrivetingâ€ (PopSugar) and â€œacutely observed family dramaâ€ (People) that delves into the lingering aftermath of a young girlâ€™s disappearance.. Ellie Mack was the perfect daughter. She was fifteen, the youngest of three. Beloved by her parents, friends, and teachers, and half of a teenaged golden couple. Ellie was days away from an idyllic post-exams summer vacation, with her whole life ahead of her. And then she was gone. Now, her mother Laurel Mack is trying to put her life back together. Itâ€™s been ten years since her daughter disappeared, seven years since her marriage ended, and only months since the last clue in Ellieâ€™s case was unearthed. So when she meets an unexpectedly charming man in a cafÃ©, no one is more surprised than Laurel at how quickly their flirtation develops into something deeper. Before she knows it, sheâ€™s meeting Floydâ€™s daughtersâ€”and his youngest, Poppy, takes Laurelâ€™s breath away. Because looking at Poppy is like looking at Ellie. And now, the unanswered questions sheâ€™s tried so hard to put to rest begin to haunt Laurel anew. Where did Ellie go? Did she really run away from home, as the police have long suspected, or was there a more sinister reason for her disappearance? Who is Floyd, really? And why does his daughter remind Laurel so viscerally of her own missing girl?

A few months ago, the last clue emerged. Then the coincidences begin â€“ or everyone knows except Laurel. She meets Floyd in a cafe, whose youngest daughter, Poppy, looks like Ellie, etc. etc. How many family members or otherwise look exactly like another? Hardly ever!Captive and abduction stories are the very types of crime novels I donâ€™t enjoy; I would have given â€œThen She Was Goneâ€ a miss if Iâ€™d known.This one was, for me, unenjoyable and unbelievable, and it wasnâ€™t page-turning. reviews.body: on the edge of my seat every minute.

reviews.title: lots of twists and turns
reviews.body: Then She Was Gone follows the story of Laurel, a mother, grappling with the mysterious disappearance of her daughter Ellie. It is ten years after Ellie disappeared that Laurel meets a stranger at a cafÃ© who brings romance back into her life. But when the man introduces Laurel to his daughter, something seems familiarâ€¦ but very wrong.I really enjoyed this one. It has lots of twists and turns as well as unique characters. Sure, there were some times when the story was a little slow, but the fast-paced curveballs really make up for it. Lisa Jewell really kept me guessing nearly the whole time with this one. I really loved the dynamics of the characters and the complex emotions. Many thriller and mystery writers are quick to skip over the ins and outs of the characters in order to get to the twists and turns, but this book does an excellent job of slowing down in the right ways to let the reader build connections. It makes the tense moments and reveals feel much more personal. Overall, a solid book that I would definitely recommend.

results.bookDescription: PULITZER PRIZE FINALIST â€¢Â Â Named a Top 10 Best Book of the Year by The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, The Atlantic, Slate, and People. One of Barack Obama's Favorite Books of 2023. â€œBrave and nuanced . . . an act of tremendous compassion and a literary triumph.â€ â€”The New York Times. â€œImmensely emotional and unforgettably haunting.â€ â€”The Wall Street JournalAcclaimed author Jonathan Rosenâ€™s haunting investigation of the forces that led his closest childhood friend, Michael Laudor, from the heights of brilliant promise to the forensic psychiatric hospital where he has lived since killing the woman he loved. A story about friendship, love, and the price of self-delusion, The Best Minds explores the ways in which we understandâ€”and fail to understandâ€”mental illness.. When the Rosens moved to New Rochelle in 1973, Jonathan Rosen and Michael Laudor became inseparable. Both children of college professors, the boys were best friends and keen competitors, and, when they both got into Yale University, seemed set to join the American meritocratic elite. Â  Michael blazed through college in three years, graduating summa cum laude and landing a top-flight consulting job. But all wasnâ€™t as it seemed. One day, Jonathan received the call: Michael had suffered a serious psychotic break and was in the locked ward of a psychiatric hospital. Â  Diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia, Michael was still battling delu­sions when he traded his halfway house for Yale Law School. Featured in The New York Times as a role model genius, he sold a memoir, with film rights to Ron Howard. But then Michael, in the grip of an unshakeable paranoid fantasy, stabbed his girlfriend Carrie to death and became a front-page story of an entirely different sort. Â  Tender, funny, and harrowing by turns, The Best Minds is Jonathan Rosenâ€™s magnificent and heartbreaking account of good intentions and tragic outcomes whose significance will echo widely.

reviews.title: The party know-it-all writes a book
reviews.body: Reading this was torture! Have you ever attended a gathering where  one person endlessly provides referenced opinions on every thing under the sun? Everything! That is this book: commonalities between literary theories and mental health, Dante's Divine Comedy, forced sterilization, Ginsberg and every possible literary name drop,  Somewhere, lost in this massive ego-stroking-on- intellect, is a story about a mental kill person who killed someone. I still had not reached that story at 40% in.  An important story gets lost in a Yale English Lit graduate course. What a huge waste of my time.

reviews.title: A masterpiece for our time
reviews.body: I could not put this book down.  In spite of it's length it was gripping due to its exquisite writing style, pathos, compassion for the subject juxtaposed against the existing mental health struggles within our system of health care.  The author has indeed written an elegy for those struggling with mental health challenges and their loved ones.  I have shared it, purchased it and recommended i t to many already.  Recommend without any reservation. Run to read this book.

reviews.title: I returned it without finishing the book.
reviews.body: And got a whopping $3 back (I'd bought it when it was on Kindle Deals), but I felt like even though it was only $3, I wanted my money back.This book, according to the description, is supposed to be about the author and his childhood friend, who struggled with mental illness and ended up killing someone. The book is actually a memoir of the author's life, which was unexceptional in almost every way. He had a very typical middle-class upbringing in an affluent suburb and had some good things happen to him, and some bad things happen to him, none of which are exceptionally notable. I got about halfway through the book and started skimming and figured out - this is honestly and truly not going anywhere, so I quit.This is the second book I have read recently that was described as being about an interesting topic, and ended up being the boring memoir of a completely unexceptional person. Is this some new trick that publishers are using to sell books - buying people's memoirs (hopefully cheap!) and then billing them as something more interesting/exciting than they actually are, just to get people to buy books? I have no idea why people thought this dry, overly-detailed recounting of someone's childhood experiences was interesting, unless maybe they're also boomers who think that the times they lived through need yet another recounting by someone who had no real involvement with the events of the era. I would skip this one - meandering and pointless.

reviews.body: Worth it.

reviews.title: MEL FANS - Read this before purchasing!
reviews.body: I am a big fan of Mel Robbins and like most of her content, however, this audio book was the exception. I should have listened more to the reviews, rather than go off of the fact that I typically like Mel's information. Nearly the entire content is interviews with individuals to go over their issues. The issues aren't that insightful and they are rehashed several times over to boot. If you like hearing people cry and get all emotional about child hood issues then this is for you. I didn't relate well to it at all, but I'm more of a suck it up and move on personality type. Mel is typically more like that so this content kind of surprised me, but it was from years ago too. I am all for being empathetic, but she's not a counselor and I don't want to be a part of others private counseling sessions. That's probably the best way to sum up the entire book, you are a witness to others counseling sessions. No thanks.

reviews.title: Love Mel!
reviews.body: I enjoyed this audiobook and found it quite useful.  Mel is terrific and does a great job helping folks like me get more out of life.  One heads up...........and Mel mentions this in the opening........Some of the language is a bit coarse so if that is a deal killer for you, then don't buy it.  I am not a fan of, in my opinion, random, silly unneeded f-bombs, but, such is the  state of our culture.

reviews.title: No respect for Author
reviews.body: No respect for an author who has to use the "f" word to make a point.  Really? A writer who is supposed to have a mastery of words and repeatedly uses a word that a 13 yr old boy would chose to use to impress his friends when trying to be cool?  I'm intentional about what I put into my mind and she lost me when she made a poor choice with her "flavorful" language.

reviews.title: Not impressed
reviews.body: She did some coaching which started out interesting. Got tired of her dropping the f bomb. Discussed with an already trouble person that she should have her boyfriend start sleeping over, chances of further screwing up her life, pretty dang high. Lost me on this one, won't purchase her other books.

reviews.title: Life Changer!!!
reviews.body: This is a fantastic book that speaks realistically and practical to the lives of everyday screwed up people and those who don't know they're screwed up people!I've just finished the book yesterday and today I downloaded the PDF workbook. I'm looking forward to engaging myself into it and listening to the book again. FEAR; known & unknown, does greatly impact our lives and so does what have happened in our past. You don't try to go back trying to fix your past but you do need to recognize it is still a part of who you are today. I have gained much truth, freedom and insight from this book. I recommend it for anyone who experiences anxieties (you may not even know that you do). If you feel like you just want to start trying to be whoever-in-this-hell-of-a-life that you are supposed to be, then read this book and... start to take control.I used the audible book, ordered a set of soft cushioned earphones and made time for me. What a treat! It's not the kind of book that has to be over once the final credits are read. I am now willing to get better and live the life that's meant for me to the best of my ability...  I am so thankful for Mel. I never knew of her until I saw this book on Amazon in my search for self-help. Thank you, lady, you've done an awesome work!!!

Twelve-year-old Rill Foss and her four younger siblings live a magical life aboard their familyâ€™s Mississippi River shantyboat. But when their father must rush their mother to the hospital one stormy night, Rill is left in chargeâ€”until strangers arrive in force. Wrenched from all that is familiar and thrown into a Tennessee Childrenâ€™s Home Society orphanage, the Foss children are assured that they will soon be returned to their parentsâ€”but they quickly realize the dark truth. At the mercy of the facilityâ€™s cruel director, Rill fights to keep her sisters and brother together in a world of danger and uncertainty.. Aiken, South Carolina, present day. Born into wealth and privilege, Avery Stafford seems to have it all: a successful career as a federal prosecutor, a handsome fiancÃ©, and a lavish wedding on the horizon. Based on one of Americaâ€™s most notorious real-life scandalsâ€”in which Georgia Tann, director of a Memphis-based adoption organization, kidnapped and sold poor children to wealthy families all over the countryâ€”Lisa Wingateâ€™s riveting, wrenching, and ultimately uplifting tale reminds us how, even though the paths we take can lead to many places, the heart never forgets where we belong.. reviews.title: Memorable Novel
reviews.body: This is a novel which is presented in two distinct parts.  One part deals with Rill Foss, a 12-year-old girl living in a shantyboat along the Mississippi River with her four younger siblings. They run afoul the Tennessee Childrenâ€™s Home Society orphanage in Menphis. The second part deal with Avery Stafford, a lawyer from a prominent South Carolina family. How these two stories come together is creative and compelling. They both deal with the true-life scandal involving the Tennessee Childrenâ€™s Home Society. If this had simply been a work of fiction, many readers would have assumed such things could not really happen. But they did and the fact that legalized kidnapping occurred is well documented in this work of historical fiction. The author has done a wonderful job of combining believable characters with this historic tragedy to produce a remarkable novel. I must admit the portion of the novel based in South Carolina is not as compelling but serves to bring these victims into the current day and thus important to the story. This is one novel you will remember for a long, long time.

results.title: Atomic Habits: An Easy & Proven Way to Build Good Habits & Break Bad Ones
results.subtitle: by        James Clear        (Author)
results.bookDescription: The #1 New York Times bestseller. Over 20 million copies sold!. Tiny Changes, Remarkable Results. No matter your goals, Atomic Habits offers a proven framework for improving--every day. James Clear, one of the world's leading experts on habit formation, reveals practical strategies that will teach you exactly how to form good habits, break bad ones, and master the tiny behaviors that lead to remarkable results.. If you're having trouble changing your habits, the problem isn't you. The problem is your system. Bad habits repeat themselves again and again not because you don't want to change, but because you have the wrong system for change. You do not rise to the level of your goals. You fall to the level of your systems. Here, you'll get a proven system that can take you to new heights.. Clear is known for his ability to distill complex topics into simple behaviors that can be easily applied to daily life and work. Here, he draws on the most proven ideas from biology, psychology, and neuroscience to create an easy-to-understand guide for making good habits inevitable and bad habits impossible. Along the way, readers will be inspired and entertained with true stories from Olympic gold medalists, award-winning artists, business leaders, life-saving physicians, and star comedians who have used the science of small habits to master their craft and vault to the top of their field.. Learn how to:Â make time for new habits (even when life gets crazy);Â overcome a lack of motivation and willpower;design your environment to make success easier;get back on track when you fall off course;...and much more.. Atomic Habits will reshape the way you think about progress and success, and give you the tools and strategies you need to transform your habits--whether you are a team looking to win a championship, an organization hoping to redefine an industry, or simply an individual who wishes to quit smoking, lose weight, reduce stress, or achieve any other goal.

results.subtitle: Matthew McConaughey        (Author, Narrator),               Random House Audio        (Publisher)
results.bookDescription: #1 NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER 6 MILLION COPIES SOLD WORLDWIDE! Now with exclusive new content from the paperback edition, the life-changing memoir that has inspired millions of listeners through the Academy Award-winning actorâ€™s unflinching honesty, unconventional wisdom, and lessons learned the hard way about living with greater satisfaction. â€œThe No. 1 celebrity memoir of the past 10 years.â€â€”USA Today â€œMcConaugheyâ€™s book invites us to grapple with the lessons of his life as he didâ€”and to see that the point was never to win, but to understand.â€â€”Mark Manson, author of The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck Iâ€™ve been in this life for fifty years, been trying to work out its riddle for forty-two, and been keeping diaries of clues to that riddle for the last thirty-five. Notes about successes and failures, joys and sorrows, things that made me marvel, and things that made me laugh out loud. How to be fair. How to have less stress. How to have fun. How to hurt people less. How to get hurt less. How to be a good man. How to have meaning in life. How to be more me. Recently, I worked up the courage to sit down with those diaries. I found stories I experienced, lessons I learned and forgot, poems, prayers, prescriptions, beliefs about what matters, some great photographs, and a whole bunch of bumper stickers. I found a reliable theme, an approach to living that gave me more satisfaction, at the time, and still: If you know how, and when, to deal with lifeâ€™s challengesâ€”how to get relative with the inevitableâ€”you can enjoy a state of success I call â€œcatching greenlights.â€ So I took a one-way ticket to the desert and wrote this book: an album, a record, a story of my life so far. This is fifty years of my sights and seens, felts and figured-outs, cools and shamefuls. Graces, truths, and beauties of brutality. Getting away withs, getting caughts, and getting wets while trying to dance between the raindrops. Hopefully, itâ€™s medicine that tastes good, a couple of aspirin instead of the infirmary, a spaceship to Mars without needing your pilotâ€™s license, going to church without having to be born again, and laughing through the tears. Itâ€™s a love letter. To life. Itâ€™s also a guide to catching more greenlightsâ€”and to realizing that the yellows and reds eventually turn green too. Good luck.

results.title: Trust (Pulitzer Prize Winner)
results.subtitle: by        Hernan Diaz        (Author)
results.bookDescription: WINNER OF THE PULITZER PRIZE FOR FICTION. ONE OF THE NEW YORK TIMESâ€™S 100 BEST BOOKS OF THE 21ST CENTURY . A NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLERONE OF BARACK OBAMA'S FAVORITE BOOKS OF 2022LONGLISTED FOR THE 2022 BOOKER PRIZE. â€œBuzzy and enthralling . . . A glorious novel about empires and erasures, husbands and wives, staggering fortunes and unspeakable misery . . . Fun as hell to read.â€ â€”Oprah Daily. "A genre-bending, time-skipping story about New York Cityâ€™s elite in the roaring â€™20s and Great Depression." â€”Vanity Fair. â€œA riveting story of class, capitalism, and greed.â€Â â€”Esquire. "Exhilarating.â€ â€”New York Times. Even through the roar and effervescence of the 1920s, everyone in New York has heard of Benjamin and Helen Rask. He is a legendary Wall Street tycoon; she is the daughter of eccentric aristocrats. Together, they have risen to the very top of a world of seemingly endless wealthâ€”all as a decade of excess and speculation draws to an end. But at what cost have they acquired their immense fortune? This is the mystery at the center of Bonds, a successful 1937 novel that all of New York seems to have read. Yet there are other versions of this tale of privilege and deceit.Â Â Â Â Hernan Diazâ€™s TRUST elegantly puts these competing narratives into conversation with one anotherâ€”and in tension with the perspective of one woman bent on disentangling fact from fiction. The result is a novel that spans over a century and becomes more exhilarating with each new revelation.Â  Â  At once an immersive story and a brilliant literary puzzle, TRUST engages the reader in a quest for the truth while confronting the deceptions that often live at the heart of personal relationships, the reality-warping force of capital, and the ease with which power can manipulate facts.

reviews.title: Tedious
reviews.body: Trust is presented in four parts.  The conceit of this format is that each part is a â€œdifferent book,â€ that cover the same topic from alternate perspectives.  There is not a linear plot, and there are really no characters of interest.  I did not see any deep insights into capitalism or greed that I have seen mentioned in other reviews.  Very disappointing.

reviews.title: A fresh jumble

reviews.title: Solid Work of Literary Fiction
reviews.body: Periodically, I try to read Pulitzer Prize nominated novels, and this was a relatively recent winner. Unlike some others in that category, I found it very approachable, and while slightly unusual, not terribly so.The book consists of four, very different, though interconnected sections.  The first is a putative work of fiction, focused on a Wall Street robber baron and his mentally challenged wife.  The second is the partially completed memoirs of the financier upon whose life the work of fiction was based.  The third focuses on the young lady who is tasked with ghost writing the memoir, whose primary charge is on the rehabilitation of the mentally unstable wife.  Finally, we are presented the journal entries of the wife herself.I enjoyed the book, though the final section really doesnâ€™t bring much to the table.  It is a solid piece of work, with good writing and interesting characters.

results.title: Talking to Strangers: What We Should Know About the People We Don't Know
results.subtitle: Malcolm Gladwell        (Author, Narrator),               Hachette Audio        (Publisher)
results.bookDescription: Malcolm Gladwell, host of the podcast Revisionist History and author of the number-one New York Times best seller Outliers, reinvents the audiobook in this immersive production of Talking to Strangers, a powerful examination of our interactions with people we donâ€™t know. How did Fidel Castro fool the CIA for a generation? Why did Neville Chamberlain think he could trust Adolf Hitler? Why are campus sexual assaults on the rise? Do television sitcoms teach us something about the way we relate to each other that isn't true? While tackling these questions, Malcolm Gladwell was not solely writing a book for the page. He was also producing for the ear. In the audiobook version of Talking to Strangers, youâ€™ll hear the voices of people he interviewed - scientists, criminologists, military psychologists. Court transcripts are brought to life with re-enactments. You actually hear the contentious arrest of Sandra Bland by the side of the road in Texas. As Gladwell revisits the deceptions of Bernie Madoff, the trial of Amanda Knox, and the suicide of Sylvia Plath, you hear directly from many of the players in these real-life tragedies. Thereâ€™s even a theme song - Janelle Monaeâ€™s â€œHell You Talmboutâ€. Something is very wrong, Gladwell argues, with the tools and strategies we use to make sense of people we don't know. And because we don't know how to talk to strangers, we are inviting conflict and misunderstanding in ways that have a profound effect on our lives and our world. The audiobook edition of Talking to Strangers was an instant number-one best seller, and was one of the most pre-ordered audiobooks in history. It seamlessly marries audiobooks and podcasts, creating a completely new and real listening experience.

reviews.title: Perfect for sophomore English

The author does a good job of regurgitating others' ideas (e.g., the psychologist Levine) and inspired me to dig deeper into some areas. The writing is good, accessible but not brilliant. Would be perfect for a sophomore English class, to get students thinking and discussing.

I've heard plenty already about Bernie Madhoff, Jerry Sandusky, and other vile human beings and how they fooled people.  I turned this off half way through and couldn't finish it.

reviews.title: Misrepresented Subject Matter

No kidding?  A waste of time and money for anyone looking for some Malcolm Gladwell brilliance.

results.bookDescription: New York Times best-seller. Over five million copies soldFor David Goggins, childhood was a nightmare--poverty, prejudice, and physical abuse colored his days and haunted his nights. But through self-discipline, mental toughness, and hard work, Goggins transformed himself from a depressed, overweight young man with no future into a US Armed Forces icon and one of the world's top endurance athletes. The only man in history to complete elite training as a Navy SEAL, Army Ranger, and Air Force tactical air controller, he went on to set records in numerous endurance events, inspiring Outside magazine to name him the Fittest (Real) Man in America.In Can't Hurt Me, he shares his astonishing life story and reveals that most of us tap into only 40 percent of our capabilities. Goggins calls this The 40% Rule, and his story illuminates a path that anyone can follow to push past pain, demolish fear, and reach their full potential.An annotated edition of Can't Hurt Me, offering over two hours of bonus content featuring deeper insights and never-before-told stories shared by David. Not available in other formats.

results.subtitle: by        Admiral William H. McRaven        (Author)
results.bookDescription: Based on a Navy SEAL's inspiring graduation speech, this #1 New York Times bestseller of powerful life lessons "should be read by every leader in America" (Wall Street Journal).. If you want to change the world, start off by making your bed.. On May 17, 2014, Admiral William H. McRaven addressed the graduating class of the University of Texas at Austin on their Commencement day. Taking inspiration from the university's slogan, "What starts here changes the world," he shared the ten principles he learned during Navy Seal training that helped him overcome challenges not only in his training and long Naval career, but also throughout his life; and he explained how anyone can use these basic lessons to change themselves-and the world-for the better.. Admiral McRaven's original speech went viral with over 10 million views. Building on the core tenets laid out in his speech, McRaven now recounts tales from his own life and from those of people he encountered during his military service who dealt with hardship and made tough decisions with determination, compassion, honor, and courage. Told with great humility and optimism, this timeless book provides simple wisdom, practical advice, and words of encouragement that will inspire readers to achieve more, even in life's darkest moments. "Powerful." --USA Today. "Full of captivating personal anecdotes from inside the national security vault." --Washington Post. "Superb, smart, and succinct." --Forbes

results.title: Those Empty Eyes: A Chilling Novel of Suspense with a Shocking Twist
results.subtitle: by        Charlie Donlea        (Author)
results.bookDescription: "Draws readers in from the first heart-stopping pages and doesn't let go until the end." â€“ Mary Kubica, New York Times bestselling author of Local Woman Missing. The bestselling author of Twenty Years Later and master of modern suspense is back with a brilliantly twisting, skillfully plotted thriller perfect for fans of Jeneva Rose and Colleen Hooverâ€™s Verity.. Alex Armstrong has changed everything about herselfâ€”her name, her appearance, her backstory. Sheâ€™s no longer the terrified teenager a rapt audience saw on television, emerging in handcuffs from the quiet suburban home the night her family was massacred. That girl, Alexandra Quinlan, nicknamed Empty Eyes by the media, was accused of the killings, fought to clear her name, and later took the stand during her highly publicized defamation lawsuit that captured the attention of the nation.. Itâ€™s been ten years since, and Alex hasnâ€™t stopped searching for answers about the night her family was killed, even as she continues to hide her real identity from true crime fanatics and grasping reporters still desperate to locate her. As a legal investigator, she works tirelessly to secure justice for others, too. People like Matthew Claymore, whoâ€™s under suspicion in the disappearance of his girlfriend, a student journalist named Laura McAllister.. Laura was about to break a major story about rape and cover-ups on her college campus. Alex believes Matthew is innocent, and unearths stunning revelations about the universityâ€™s faculty, fraternity members, and powerful parents willing to do anything to protect their children.. Most shocking of allâ€”as Alex digs into Lauraâ€™s disappearance, she realizes there are unexpected connections to the murder of her own family. For as different as the crimes may seem, they each hinge on one sinister truth: no one is quite who they seem to be . . .. â€œEngrossingâ€¦not to be missed.â€ â€“Publishers Weekly STARRED REVIEW

results.title: All the Broken Places: A Novel
results.subtitle: by        John Boyne        (Author)
results.bookDescription: â€œYou canâ€™t prepare yourself for the magnitude and emotional impact of this powerful novel.â€ â€”John Irving. From the New York Times bestselling author John Boyne, a stunning tour de force about a woman who must confront the sins of her own terrible past, and a present in which it is never too late for bravery. Ninety-one-year-old Gretel Fernsby has lived in the same well-to-do mansion block in London for decades. She lives a quiet, comfortable life, despite her deeply disturbing, dark past. She doesnâ€™t talk about her escape from Nazi Germany at age twelve. She doesnâ€™t talk about the grim postwar years in France with her mother. Most of all, she doesnâ€™t talk about her father, who was the commandant of one of the Reichâ€™s most notorious extermination camps.. Then, a new family moves into the apartment below her. In spite of herself, Gretel canâ€™t help but begin a friendship with the little boy, Henry, though his presence brings back memories she would rather forget. One night, she witnesses a disturbing, violent argument between Henryâ€™s beautiful mother and his arrogant father, one that threatens Gretelâ€™s hard-won, self-contained existence.. Immersive, chilling, unputdownable, All the Broken Places moves back and forth in time between Gretelâ€™s girlhood in Germany and present-day London. Here, Gretel is at a similar crossroads to the one she encountered long ago. Then, she denied her own complicity, but now, faced with a chance to interrogate her guilt, grief, and remorse, she can choose to save a young boy. If she does, she will be forced to reveal the secrets she has spent a lifetime protecting. This time, she can make a different choice than beforeâ€”whatever the cost to herself.

results.title: The Waiting: A Ballard and Bosch Novel (A RenÃ©e Ballard and Harry Bosch Novel, 6)
results.subtitle: by        Michael Connelly        (Author)
results.bookDescription: ANÂ INSTANT #1 NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER. LAPD Detective RenÃ©e Ballard tracks a serial rapist whose trail has gone cold, and enlists a new volunteer to the Open-Unsolved Unit: patrol officer Maddie Bosch, Harryâ€™s daughter.. RenÃ©e Ballard and the LAPDâ€™s Open-Unsolved Unit get a hot shot DNA connection between a recently arrested man and a serial rapist and murderer who went quiet two decades ago. The arrested man is only twenty-four, so the genetic link must be familial: His father was the Pillowcase Rapist, responsible for a five-year reign of terror in the City of Angels. But when Ballard and her team move in on their suspect, they encounter a baffling web of secrets and legal hurdles.. Meanwhile, Ballardâ€™s badge, gun, and ID are stolenâ€”a theft she canâ€™t report without giving her enemies in the department ammunition to end her career as a detective. She works the burglary alone, but her mission draws her into unexpected danger. With no choice but to go outside the department for help, she knocks on the door of Harry Bosch.. At the same time, Ballard takes on a new volunteer to the cold case unit: Boschâ€™s daughter Maddie, now a patrol officer. But Maddie has an ulterior motive for getting access to the cityâ€™s library of lost soulsâ€”a case that may be the most iconic in the cityâ€™s history. Complex, satisfying, and full of dexterous twists, The Waiting demonstrates once more that â€œyou canâ€™t do better than Michael Connellyâ€ (Forbes).

reviews.title: Almost great
reviews.body: I'm pretty sure I've read everything of Michael's.The book is 'good', it's just not 'great'.As a huge fan it is always comforting for me to read one of his books, but after 3 decades he's not quite what he used to be and frankly neither am I.I've been spoiled by such great stuff that it's impossible to continue to expect him to outdo himself every time.I didn't get choked up the way I usually do at certain points, Maddie was never in danger, Ballard neither.Harry had a very limited role.And while a few storylines are woven together it just didn't really compel me the way a great work optimally should.I will continue to read everything Michael offers. And I love the Bosch TV series, and The Lincoln lawyer TV series.But like a lot of great authors I feel like Michael's first 5 or 10 books were by far his very best.The books where we got to really know Harry Bosch, where his biography unfolds, or who se childhood scars were revealed, where he evolved through his early and middle years on the police force as a detective.I don't see how one continues to be driven to new heights and to pull out the very best, every time.Meanwhile a 4 star Michael Connelly book is still enjoyable and thoughtful and it's crafted by a very special artist who still has a beautiful style.

reviews.title: Robuster
reviews.body: I am a firm believer that good writing is an artistic achievement. Not all writers ever rise to the level of "" art""  but this story and this writer have risen to that top bar.This was an excellent story with an outstanding hook.  It was wrote to be read quickly and not a lot of useless information for the reader to suffer under.  Which I appreciate more than I can say.  Its a great , easy to read book about the cold case of Elizabeth Short crime saga. Ballard, the lead detective in a cold case unit of primarily volentier staff uncover long hidden pictures of the Short murder which prove who her murderer to br. Politics between departments cause the case to be held up some what.The Elizabeth Short murder may be!the most notable unsolved murder in America since the 1900s.The Bosh series have several books that ring that bell of greatness , this is the first Ballard book that climbs that ladder of achievement.I am a long tenured fan of Mr. Connelly and the Harry Bosh series therefore I  am glad to see the on going of this series and the high level of work that is given to it.

reviews.title: Another winner
reviews.body: The Waiting by Michael Connelly is a masterful exploration of suspense and human resilience. Known for his gripping crime stories, Connelly delves into a more intimate narrative here, weaving a tale that is both emotionally charged and filled with quiet tension. The story follows a protagonist waiting for an uncertain outcome, drawing readers into their inner turmoil and the slow unraveling of buried truths.Connellyâ€™s prose is as sharp as ever, building an atmosphere of quiet dread while offering moments of profound introspection. While the pacing may feel slower compared to his usual high-octane thrillers, this shift allows for a deeper dive into character development and psychological nuance. Fans of Connellyâ€™s work will appreciate his ability to step into a different narrative style without losing the trademark intensity of his storytelling.A compelling read for those who enjoy psychological dramas with a touch of mystery.
